instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.A1465: What is A1465? A1465 is a model number for a 11 inch size MacBook Air from years Early 2015, Mid 2012, Mid 2013, Early 2014 with EMC 2924, that may contain one of these boards depending on the year & configuration: 820-00164, 820-3208, 820-3435..
definitions.820-3435: What is 820-3435? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.D7701: What is D7701? diode in the backlight circuit sitting between the BKL_SW pin of the LED driver and backlight output. Very common for via between this and BKL_FB for feedback to blow, causing no boost. Measure continuity between pin 2 of this diode and feedback pin of LED driver if backlight output is PPBUS_G3H with no boost.
definitions.A1369: What is A1369? A1369 is a model number for a 13 inch size MacBook Air from years Late 2010, Mid 2011 with EMC 2392, that may contain one of these boards depending on the year & configuration: 820-2838, 820-3023..
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.PPHV_S0SW_LCDBKLT: What is PPHV_S0SW_LCDBKLT? PPHV_S0SW_LCDBKLT is a power rail that powers the backlight on the LCD screen, this is necessary to get the screen to light up..
definitions.PPVIN_S0SW_LCDBKLT: What is PPVIN_S0SW_LCDBKLT? PPVIN_S0SW_LCDBKLT is PPBUS_G3H backlight voltage entering the backlight boost circuit once the transistor has been told to allow it through. .
definitions.LCDBKLT_BOOST: What is LCDBKLT_BOOST? LCDBKLT_BOOST is connected to the SWITCH(SW) pin of the LED driver and is switched to ground quickly after the inductor in the DC to DC boost circuit that boosts PPBUS_G3H to backlight voltage for the screen. .
definitions.BLK_EN: What is BLK_EN? This is a typo of BKL_EN When you see BLK_EN, assume they meant to type BKL_EN.
definitions.EDP_BKLT_EN: What is EDP_BKLT_EN? This is an enable signal. Anytime you see “_EN”, it means when the voltage is high(3.3 volts), whatever it is going to is being turned on or enabled. Here, “EDP_BKLT” which stands for “embedded displayport backlight” is being enabled. This signal usually goes to an LED driver used for creating a power rail for the LCD screen backlight, to tell it to turn on & create this rail. .
definitions.Q7706: What is Q7706? Q7706 takes PPBUS_G3H's main 12.6v and sends it through to the backlight circuit. If Q9706 is not allowing PPBUS_G3H through, you will get no voltage on the backlight circuit. Q7706 is a P channel MOSFET, meaning power will flow through it when the voltage on the gate is lower than on the source. Look at pin 3. R7788 takes the 12.6v that is on the source and places it right on pin 3. This will set Q7706 to "off", and not allow it to pass power, as the voltage on the source and the gate are identical..
definitions.SMC_LID: What is SMC_LID? SMC_LID tells the machine the system is open when it is 3.3v to 3.4v, and closed when it is low such as 0v-0.6v. When this signal is low, the machine may go to sleep or have no backlight. .
definitions.EDP_BKLT_PWM: What is EDP_BKLT_PWM? EDP_BKLT_PWM sets the brightness of the screen. The system will send a PWM signal to BKL_PWM pin to set brightness. If this is low, backlight voltage will boost higher than PPBUS_G3H input, but not enough to make the screen light properly..
definitions.A1466: What is A1466? A1466 is a model number for a 13 inch size MacBook Air from years Early 2015, 2017, Mid 2012, Mid 2013, Early 2014 with EMC 2925, that may contain one of these boards depending on the year & configuration: 820-00165, 820-3209, 820-3437..
definitions.820-3437: What is 820-3437? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.

threads.title: MacBook Air <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1465</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3435</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> green light, boots, chime, but no backlight.
threads.message:
I’m new to repair. I am a laid off newspaper photographer looking for a transition to a different career. I’ve done pretty well so far. I started with G4 Powerbooks and progressed to 2010’s MacBook Pros and Airs  I usually buy broken MacBooks on eBay to learn, practice and repair. My latest purchases has been a 2013 MacBook Air 11” <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1465</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> and 2011 13” <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1369</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>. 

My question today is with the MacBook Air 11” with the <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3435</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> board. I know the MacBook Air no backlight issue is not new, but I could use some guidance. 

I get green light, boot and chime, but no backlight. I do get an image and can see a blinking folder if I shine a light behind the screen. I thought it would be a simple change of <CHIP>U7701</CHIP>, but no. I still have no backlight. The screen connector cable has no damage, nor is there damage to the LVDS connector on the board. 

LVDS connector pin 18 and 19 - 3.32v - pin 3 and 4 - .001v
<CAPACITOR>C8317</CAPACITOR> -    pin 1-  <SIGNAL>PPHV_S0SW_LCDBKLT</SIGNAL> - .001v
<DIODE>D7701</DIODE> -    pin 2 - <SIGNAL>PPHV_S0SW_LCDBKLT</SIGNAL> - .001v
                  pin 1 - <SIGNAL>LCDBKLT_BOOST</SIGNAL> - .001v    
<CAPACITOR>C7799</CAPACITOR> -    pin 1 - <SIGNAL>PPHV_S0SW_LCDBKLT</SIGNAL> - .001v
L7701 -     pin 1 - <SIGNAL>PPVIN_S0SW_LCDBKLT</SIGNAL> - .001v
                  pin 2 - <SIGNAL>LCDBKLT_BOOST</SIGNAL> - .001v
F7700 -     pin 1 - <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> - 8.58v
                  pin 2 - PPVIN_S0SW_LCDBKLTFET - 8.58v
<RESISTOR>R7715</RESISTOR> -     pin 1 - <SIGNAL>BLK_EN</SIGNAL> - .001v
<RESISTOR>R7731</RESISTOR> -     pin 1 - <SIGNAL>BLK_EN</SIGNAL> - .001v

There is continuity and no broken traces between <DIODE>D7701</DIODE> pin 1 to L7701 pin 2 or the test pad near by. 

I know there is something I am missing, but can’t seem to find the issue. Any help would be greatly appreciated.

threads.title: MacBook Air <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1465</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3435</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> green light, boots, chime, but no backlight.
threads.message:
First of all, welcome to the forum!

If you write a signal name, or power rail, no need to mention component and pin where to check; we will find it.
And the post is more easy readable.

Check voltage for <SIGNAL>EDP_BKLT_EN</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>BKLT_PLT_RST_L</SIGNAL>.
If both present, post <TRANSISTOR>Q7706</TRANSISTOR> voltages.

threads.title: MacBook Air <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1465</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3435</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> green light, boots, chime, but no backlight.
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>EDP_BKLT_EN</SIGNAL> - .001v
<SIGNAL>BKLT_PLT_RST_L</SIGNAL> - 3.34V

threads.title: MacBook Air <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1465</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3435</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> green light, boots, chime, but no backlight.
threads.message:
Really strange, as you get image.
Check <SIGNAL>EDP_BKLT_PWM</SIGNAL> too.
Be sure <SIGNAL>SMC_LID</SIGNAL> is steady high, just in case.
Do PRAM reset 2-3 times.

Post diode mode to ground at K/<DIODE>D7701</DIODE>, w/ and w/o LCD connected.

threads.title: MacBook Air <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1465</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3435</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> green light, boots, chime, but no backlight.
threads.message:
I did the PRAM rest no change. I still have an image, but no backlight.

<SIGNAL>EDP_BKLT_PWM</SIGNAL> - 1.478v
<SIGNAL>SMC_LID</SIGNAL> - 3.43v

diode check on <DIODE>D7701</DIODE> produced OL on both sides with and without LCD connected. 
Unsure what "K/" means

I replaced <DIODE>D7701</DIODE> from a <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1466</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> board that share parts. On that board in diode mode it read .561. However when I placed it on the 11" board it again read OL on both sides. I guess that brings me closer to the issue.

threads.title: MacBook Air <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1465</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3435</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> green light, boots, chime, but no backlight.
threads.message:
I am guessing you mean L7701 when you typed "K"

At L7701 I am getting the same OL reading.

threads.title: MacBook Air <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1465</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3435</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> green light, boots, chime, but no backlight.
threads.message:
ALWAYS measure diode mode with red probe connected to ground.
I suppose you will get correct readings on both boards then.
You cannot get OL measuring in correct way!

If you pay attention to schematic, <DIODE>D7701</DIODE> has two terminals; A (anode) and K (cathode).

threads.title: MacBook Air <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1465</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3435</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> green light, boots, chime, but no backlight.
threads.message:
Yup. Measured with Red as ground on screw hole nearest the area. That’s how I got the .561 on the donor board. Once I soldered the diode on to the board, I again got the OL on both sides. I even changed my test leads on my Fluk. Similar reading. 
 
I checked a photo of the board before I changed anything and do have proper orientation.

threads.title: MacBook Air <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1465</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3435</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> green light, boots, chime, but no backlight.
threads.message: Then you have broken traces, or bad solders on the board.

threads.title: MacBook Air <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1465</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3435</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> green light, boots, chime, but no backlight.
threads.message: Okay, I will check and get back to you. Thank-you.

threads.title: MacBook Air <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1465</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3435</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> green light, boots, chime, but no backlight.
threads.message:
I don't know with this board. I removed everything on this line that has been giving me an OL. I wicked up the solder and check the pads for continuity. I got tone on each connected pad. I checked Olms on each piece and got good readings. I resoldered the pieces and OL again. 

I again removed each piece, wicked up the solder and changed my solder and only placed the <DIODE>D7701</DIODE> onto the board. OL again. 

I do check other components to see if I get a proper diode reading and I do. It's just this line that I get OL on all pads with the components soldered onto the board. 

These are the pieces I removed - all associated with either
<SIGNAL>PPHV_S0SW_LCDBKLT</SIGNAL>
<SIGNAL>LCDBKLT_BOOST</SIGNAL>

L7701
<DIODE>D7701</DIODE>
<CAPACITOR>C7799</CAPACITOR>
<CAPACITOR>C7797</CAPACITOR>
<CAPACITOR>C8317</CAPACITOR>

I appreciate the help, but I may just move on from this board unless something new can be suggested. This one baffles me.

threads.title: MacBook Air <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1465</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3435</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> green light, boots, chime, but no backlight.
threads.message:
OL means no connection with other components.
What do you expect removing even more components???
Please, try to pout a logic on your job!

"only  placed the <DIODE>D7701</DIODE> onto the board. OL again"
This is indeed VERY good reading, as no other component is connected there to ground; you already removed all.

You need to find why don't get similar readings like in other board.
<CHIP>U7701</CHIP> is connected with both pins of <DIODE>D7701</DIODE>.
It has lot of internal components, which makes it indicates something in diode mode; IF you correctly check, with black probe on pin and red probe at ground.

threads.title: MacBook Air <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1465</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3435</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> green light, boots, chime, but no backlight.
threads.message: I understand that, but when I place <DIODE>D7701</DIODE> back on the donor board, I get a reading (one cap missing). Again I am placing red probe on a ground point (actually several) while in diode mode. And it is the correct setting on my Fluk. I do get readings on other locations, just not on those lines. I will try again with the components back in their location.

threads.title: MacBook Air <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1465</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3435</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> green light, boots, chime, but no backlight.
threads.message:
Did you check continuity from <DIODE>D7701</DIODE> to <CHIP>U7701</CHIP>?

All components (especially <CHIP>U7701</CHIP>) must be soldered on the board, when you check diode mode to ground readings.

threads.title: MacBook Air <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1465</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3435</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> green light, boots, chime, but no backlight.
threads.message: Okay. I will place everything back on in the morning and recheck. I will check continuity with <DIODE>D7701</DIODE> to <CHIP>U7701</CHIP>. Thanks again for the suggestions.

threads.title: MacBook Air <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1465</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3435</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> green light, boots, chime, but no backlight.
threads.message:
Back on track. Please remember I am a newbie. When I went to check continuity with <DIODE>D7701</DIODE>, it lifted a bit. That would explain the OL. I reseated it and now have proper readings on everything. 

<SIGNAL>PPHV_S0SW_LCDBKLT</SIGNAL> - .007

<DIODE>D7701</DIODE> in diode mode 
with screen connect - .591 and .405
without - .602 and .409

<SIGNAL>LCDBKLT_BOOST</SIGNAL> - .007

Voltages at <TRANSISTOR>Q7706</TRANSISTOR>
<SIGNAL>PPVIN_S0SW_LCDBKLT_FET</SIGNAL>  - .006

<SIGNAL>LCDBKLT_EN_DIV_L</SIGNAL> - 8.32

PPVIN_S0SW_LCDBKLTFET - 8.57

threads.title: MacBook Air <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1465</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3435</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> green light, boots, chime, but no backlight.
threads.message:
"<SIGNAL>PPHV_S0SW_LCDBKLT</SIGNAL> - .007
--------------
<SIGNAL>LCDBKLT_BOOST</SIGNAL> - .007"
What these readings are?
Diode mode can't as, you don get same readings on <DIODE>D7702</DIODE>.
And voltage, I don't think; unless you like (out of reason) to check voltages with 3 digit after zero...

Do you still get image?
Remove <TRANSISTOR>Q7707</TRANSISTOR> and tie together pads 1 & 3.
Check <DIODE>D7701</DIODE> voltages again.

Keep LCD connected.

threads.title: MacBook Air <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1465</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3435</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> green light, boots, chime, but no backlight.
threads.message:
I still get image, but no backlight. Blinking folder appears only with flashlight on back of screen.

I removed <TRANSISTOR>Q7707</TRANSISTOR> and jumped pads 1 & 3. 

Voltages at <DIODE>D7701</DIODE> with screen connected

<SIGNAL>LCDBKLT_BOOST</SIGNAL> - .016
<SIGNAL>PPHV_S0SW_LCDBKLT</SIGNAL> - .016

threads.title: MacBook Air <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1465</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3435</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> green light, boots, chime, but no backlight.
threads.message:
Post <TRANSISTOR>Q7706</TRANSISTOR> voltages now.
Be sure F7700 is good.

threads.title: MacBook Air <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1465</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3435</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> green light, boots, chime, but no backlight.
threads.message:
Sorry for the delay, day job... 

<TRANSISTOR>Q7707</TRANSISTOR> with jumper on pads 1 & 3

<TRANSISTOR>Q7706</TRANSISTOR>
<SIGNAL>LCDBKLT_EN_DIV_L</SIGNAL> - 8.31
PPVIN_S0SW_LCDBKLTFET  - 8.58
<SIGNAL>PPVIN_S0SW_LCDBKLT_FET</SIGNAL> - .101

F7700 is good.
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> - 8.58
PPVIN_S0SW_LCDBKLTFET  - 8.58

threads.title: MacBook Air <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1465</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3435</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> green light, boots, chime, but no backlight.
threads.message:
"<SIGNAL>LCDBKLT_EN_DIV_L</SIGNAL> - 8.31"
<RESISTOR>R7789</RESISTOR> open, <CAPACITOR>C7782</CAPACITOR> with leakage, or bad <TRANSISTOR>Q7706</TRANSISTOR>...

threads.title: MacBook Air <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1465</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3435</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> green light, boots, chime, but no backlight.
threads.message:
Interesting. My photos of the board when I first pulled it out of the laptop has no <RESISTOR>R7789</RESISTOR> in place. 

I just checked the top pad 

<SIGNAL>LCDBKLT_EN_DIV_L</SIGNAL> - 8.32

Maybe previous owner knocked it off, which is why I was able to buy it on eBay cheaply. 

I will check my donor board and replace. 

Thx. I will get back to you.

threads.title: MacBook Air <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1465</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3435</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> green light, boots, chime, but no backlight.
threads.message:
All set thank-you so much for all the help 2informaticos!. It was the missing resistor <RESISTOR>R7789</RESISTOR>. I have screen image.

This has definitely taught me to look over the board and match things up with my boardview app. 

This forum is by far the best help out there.
